I‚Äôm making a process argument not a substantive one. There is plenty to say on substance. And the question of balance is an interesting one but not one we‚Äôve addressed. That doesn‚Äôt mean I believe our thinking should be ‚Äúpurely political‚Äù.

Really? First of all, what is ‚Äúright‚Äù is almost never obvious. And second, the House of Representatives exists to act on the will of the people (as understood by representatives). Are you proposing a different system?

Advocating with your representative is not ludicrous. It is at the very core of our democracy. Are you arguing that the way forward here is totally obvious? What if someone out there disagrees with you?

Well, threats are not the most persuasive form of argument, but if you read my tweets, you will see that I have spent the evening arguing for us to reflect on what our constituents want. Here and in swing states.

And I‚Äôm sorry, play back for me what is disappointing to you. All I‚Äôve said all night is that we should do some due diligence on public sentiment here. I‚Äôm kinda hung on that ‚ÄúRepresentative‚Äù part of my title.
Ah. A response so thoughtful and considered that I can‚Äôt believe it‚Äôs on Twitter.

I‚Äôm not saying we don‚Äôt try. I‚Äôm saying that we consider public opinion. That is why this particular function rests with the legislature, not the judiciary, which is theoretically insulated from public opinion.
Yeah. Except that I‚Äôm not saying any of that.
I don‚Äôt know. Do you?
I don‚Äôt think you‚Äôre reading very carefully. I‚Äôm not saying we don‚Äôt impeach or that we don‚Äôt do our duty. I am saying we should consider public sentiment. Like say, yours.
I don‚Äôt think you‚Äôre reading very carefully. I‚Äôm not saying we don‚Äôt impeach or that we don‚Äôt do our duty. I am saying we should consider public sentiment. Like say, yours.

So I don‚Äôt know where you are seeing me say we should ignore anything. I‚Äôm not arguing against impeachment. In fact I am arguing for taking our responsibility seriously by considering public sentiment.
Again. I challenge you to find where in my tweets tonight I say we should not impeach or hold him accountable.
So I challenge you to find the part in my tweets tonight where I say we shouldn‚Äôt impeach. Either show that to me or change tack.
Ah. The ad hominem attack. Always a sign....
That is a fair point. It is possible. We should consider that too.

Thought experiment: Let‚Äôs stipulate that Trump will not be removed by impeachment. And let‚Äôs stipulate the possibility that impeachment meaningfully increases his chance of re-election (something I don‚Äôt know right now). What do you do?
No. Which is why that particular function rests in the judiciary, not the legislature. But prosecutors make charge/no charge decisions every single day.

Not exactly what I‚Äôm saying. Historically, Congress has impeached, and will again. But nothing in the constitution forces Congress to impeach in a given circumstance. If you disagree, send me the language that forces Congress to do so.

Where Matt, do I say it is ‚Äúall political‚Äù? Seriously. I am a huge defender of the press. But it‚Äôs hard to do that when I take the time to engage with you and you mistate my argument. Or talk about my ‚Äúlook‚Äù. Are you trying to get at the truth here, or to stir the pot?
No. And I‚Äôm not arguing that.
I know the facts. And again, I‚Äôm not arguing for doing nothing. I‚Äôm arguing for acting in a smart and considered way.
I know Twitter is a universe where logic is not important, but I‚Äôm not arguing for doing nothing, I‚Äôm arguing for doing what we do in a fully informed way.
I think you‚Äôre not reading it very carefully.
As a non lawyer, I couldn‚Äôt agree more.

There is no explicit duty as there is conduct a census every 10 years. Congress decides if and when to impeach independent of the words of the constitution. That‚Äôs not controversial. It‚Äôs true. So it‚Äôs not unreasonable to try to understand where American sentiment is in deciding.

Lordy. It‚Äôs not about a look. Duty is in quotes because the constitution imposes absolutely no obligation to impeach under any circumstance. It‚Äôs at the discretion of Congress. Kinda feels like you‚Äôre looking for a lot more fireworks than you‚Äôre going to find in this quarter.

Like everything else a legislator does, there‚Äôs a mix of ‚Äúknowing‚Äù and what public sentiment demands. Especially in the House, where we are called ‚ÄúRepresentative‚Äù. Impeachment could have been granted to SCOTUS, but instead, it was given to the part of our gov closest to people.

I don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs an opposition between the two in this case. Impeachment is by design a political act, not a judicial or legal one. So public sentiment is as essential (probably more) as any implicit constitutional ‚Äúduty‚Äù.
Anyway, I was making an argument for care and consideration of facts and implications in however we choose to act. I expressed no view on how we should act.
I made the case, because along with the will of my constituents, that would be something I would want to know before developing intense conviction. You know, be as informed as possible before acting?

I don‚Äôt know what you heard, but I wasn‚Äôt forceful about not impeaching Trump (your words). I was forceful about making sure we had the best picture possible of how impeachment plays in Presidential swing states. Something I don‚Äôt know. See the diff?
